Atom-level interfacial synergy of single-atom site catalysts for electrocatalysis Yao Wang Dingsheng Wang ⁎ Yadong Li Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China Department of Chemistry Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Regulating the surrounding environment of active sites, including electron structure and coordination environment via atom-level interface regulation, to design and construct an advanced SACs is of great significance for boosting electrocatalytic reactions. Single-atom site catalysts (SACs) have made great achievements due to their nearly 100% atomic utilization and uniform active sites. Regulating the surrounding environment of active sites, including electron structure and coordination environment via atom-level interface regulation, to design and construct an advanced SACs is of great significance for boosting electrocatalytic reactions. In this review, we systemically summarized the fundamental understandings and intrinsic mechanisms of SACs for electrocatalytic applications based on the interface site regulations. We elaborated the several different regulation strategies of SACs to demonstrate their ascendancy in electrocatalytic applications. Firstly, the interfacial electronic interaction was presented to reveal the electron transfer behavior of active sites. Secondly, the different coordination structures of metal active center coordinated with two or three non-metal elements were also summarized. In addition, other atom-level interfaces of SACs, including metal atom–atom interface, metal atom-X-atom interface (X: non-metal element), metal atom-particle interface, were highlighted and the corresponding promoting effect towards electrocatalysis was disclosed. Finally, we outlooked the limitations, perspectives and challenges of SACs based on atomic interface regulation. Keywords Single-atom site catalysts Interface regulation Electronic interactions Coordination environment Electrocatalytic reaction 1 Introduction Increasing energy demand and rising environmental concern are the focus of the current society, which call for clean and sustainable technologies, such as proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) and metal–air batteries [1–3]. Among the amounts of energy conversions and storages, electrocatalytic reactions dominate the whole process during their applications, simultaneously, electrocatalysis are considered as the focus of deriving energy transformation. For example, CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) can reduce the reserves of CO2 greenhouse gas, triggering from the fossil-fueled [4–7]. Electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) will significantly reduce the energy need for the industrial production of ammonia [8–10]. In addition, in the metal-air batteries, such as Zn-air battery, Li-air battery, greatly depend on the catalytic performance of oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [11–13]. Moreover, enormous researcher acquired clean H2 energy from the water dissociation process, to realizing the commercial demands of “New energy economy” [14–18]. The traditional commercial noble-metal based catalysts serious limited their large-scale applications due to high cost and rare reserves. Thus, the pursuit for above industrial demands stimulates the rapid exploration of advanced catalysts to meet the criteria standards of decreasing the catalyst usage and endowing catalysts with excellent performance [19]. In this case, considerable efforts have been switched into advanced electrocatalysts, in recent years, such as, downsizing the particles to nanoscale or to atom-scale, constructing unique structure, coupling with other foreign components. Today, the expanding single-atom site electrocatalysts (SACs) has been revolutionizing the traditional commercial catalysts, from which emerges the new concept of “single-atom catalysis”. A pioneering work reported by Zhang et al. in 2011 developed a Fe-based SACs (denoted Fe1/FeO x ), which showed an enhanced CO oxidation reaction [20]. In comparison with conventional particles, the SACs possess unique isolated site configuration, electronic structure and catalytic behavior [21–24]. As a new generation of catalysts, the SACs feature abundant advantages than particles, because the active sites of SACs are uniform and atomically dispersed, which is of great significant for in-depth understanding the physico-chemical property of real-sites and intrinsic mechanism of reaction. The above superiorities are sorely lacking for particles. Although great breakthroughs toward preparation of SACs have been made recently [25–38], the key issue that rational design and construct the SACs with excellent electrocatalytic performance at the atom-level is not solved well with a mature guiding philosophy. The active sites of SACs usually anchored on the suitable support, which accompanied by complex interface environment, resulting in a complicated catalytic pathways and unexpected intermediates. Interfacial catalysis plays an important role in field of catalysis all the time [39–42]. When the interface effect comes into the SACs, the combination of uniform active sites and complicated interbonding environment will make it interesting to explore the catalytic behavior. Herein, we focus on the design and construction of atom-level sites interface of SACs on the corresponding electrocatalytic reaction. Firstly, the strong metal-support interactions trigger the interfacial electronic transfer between single active center and support, which acts as a bridge between theoretical study and experimental exploration [43,44]. Secondly, the metal active center usually anchored on the supports by coordinating with non-metal elements. Regulating the interfacial coordination environment with precision can optimize the electronic structure, as well as the adsorption/desorption energy [45,46]. Thirdly, constructing the dual-atom metal sites not only steer the interactions between the interbonding metal active atoms, but also induce a synergistic catalysis to reactions. In addition, N-bridged, O-bridged metal–metal synergistic sites are also documented to improve the electrocatalytic performance [47–49]. Fourth, engineering intimate atom-particle interface is another efficient strategy to realize the synergistic catalysis via integrating the merits of particle and single-atom sites. In deep, through controlling the morphology, size, composition, crystal phase of particle to master the geometry and electronic structure could extend catalytic limitation of catalysts [50–52]. Finally, we highlight brief conclusions and perspective for constructing advanced SACs towards electrocatalytic reactions based on the atom-level interfacial synergy. 2 Interfacial modulation strategy for SACs Surface and interface in the nanocatalysis fields greatly dominate the reaction performance, because all catalytic behaviors occur on the exposed active sites. Regulating the surface structure and modulating the physico-chemical property of active sites to obtain a better performance should be given priority. In SACs system, it is of great significance to steer the electron structure and coordination environment of metal active center to optimize the adsorption and desorption energy of intermediates during the reaction process. The concomitant synergistic effect of bonding-site is not ignored at the atom-level interface, such as Langmuir–Hinshelwood principle (L-H principle), cascade reaction principle. Constructing desired interface site in SACs system is needed to tune the targeted active center with precision, as well as to establish a defined avenue of structure-performance relationship. Herein, we demonstrate the different atomic interface design strategy and potential applications in electrocatalytic reactions, as illustrated in Fig. 1 . 2.1 Interfacial electronic modulation of isolated single sites SACs are usually supported and anchored on the specific supports as the formation of single atom. Physical properties among spin, charge, orbital, and lattice degrees of freedom of isolated atom are governed by related supports to some extent, leading an inevitable strong metal-support interaction. The following catalytic behavior and reaction pathway are strongly affected by outer sphere electron density and orbit position. In 1980s, J. K. Nørskov et al. explored the influence of d-band centers at the catalyst surface/interfaces towards catalytic activity [53,54]. According to the Sabatier principle, the interactions between the catalyst surface atoms and the reactant should be neither too strong nor too weak, demonstrating the presence of maximum catalytic activity to some extent. As the d-orbitals of precious metals, such as Pt, Ru, Rh, Ir and Os are not filled, the surface of their nanoparticles is easy to adsorb reactants in comparison with non-noble metals. Therefore, precious metal nanocatalysts have a good catalytic activity. They deeply further demonstrated the relationships between intrinsic property of active center and reactants from three aspects: the d-band center of metal active centers, filling-degree of d-orbitals of metal active centers, the coupling matrix element between the adsorbate states and d-states of metal active sites. Constructing interfacial SACs catalysis and tuning the electronic interactions of metal centers and support could enhance the catalytic activity, selectivity and stability, as well as anti-poison ability. In the field of electrocatalysis, the carbon materials, some complexes, including transition metal nitride (TMN), transition metal dichalcogenides (TMD), and so on, were used as desired support to construct different type of SACs. It is accepted that atomic M-Nx moieties in the M-N-C catalysts are regarded as the intrinsic active sites for the ORR [55–57]. Sun et al. designed a high-efficiency Cu based SACs through tuning the chemical valence of Cu ion [58]. In general, the catalysts with different Cu oxidation were prepared through the pyrolysis of Cu precursor, urea and porous carbon materials at high temperature. The detailed synthesis procedure and obtained Cu-NC SACs are illustrated in Fig. 2 a-c. Under the impact of decomposition of urea, the ammonia gas acting as a reducing agent, reduced the Cu2+ to Cu1+ state and generating Cu1+-N site during the pyrolysis process. The resulting ORR revealed that the ORR activity increased with the addition of Cu1+ sites, as illustrated in Fig. 2d. The optimal Cu1+-SA/NC(meso)-7 catalyst possessed a high half-wave potential of 0.898 V vs.RHE in basic solution, as well as a large kinetic current density of 5.36 mA cm−2 at 0.9 V. The further theoretical calculation discloses that the high-density dispersed Cu1+ sites has a favorable binding energy with OOH− adsorptions during the ORR process (Fig. 2e), in favor of alkaline ORR performance. In addition, enormous researchers steered the electronic interactions between metal active center and support through modulating the chemical valence of active centers, thus improving their catalytic performance. However, introducing the isolated single atom into the support lattice to warp original electron distribution and constructing novel interfacial electronic distribution. Emerging as an efficient and inexpensive alternative to Pt for ORR, perovskite oxides have aroused giant expectations. Precise control of the physical correlations among spin, charge, orbital, and lattice degrees of freedom in these oxides should have exercised considerable enhancement of their ORR activity, but has until now remained elusive. Recently, Zhuang et al. showed that nonmagnetic hexavalent molybdenum (Mo6+) atomically dispersed within oxide lattice steered the intrinsic activity of catalytically active sites by entrapping extrinsic electrons at their 3d orbitals, excludes the occurrence of lattice symmetry breaking and magnetic perturbation [59]. They first use ferromagnetic La2Co2+Mn4+O6 as a model catalyst (Fig. 2f), which is implanted with low-dose Mo6+([Kr]4d 05s 0) as electron traps without introducing extra magnetic moment. This catalyst therefore retains the original lattice ordering (Fig. 2g) and ferromagnetism while unnecessary electron localizations are eliminated, which helps to better identify the role of strong electron correlations on ORR catalysis. Such electron trapping generates additional high-spin, catalytically active Mn3+(t 2 g 3 eg 1) sites and highly conductive Co2+(eg 2)-O-Mn3+(eg 1) double exchange channels in catalyst (Fig. 2h), leading to a high ORR activity five-fold than pristine one and even comparable to state-of-the-art Pt. They extend this design philosophy readily to other four oxide catalysts and achieve large enhancements in their ORR activities as anticipated (Fig. 2i), indicating its broad utility. More importantly, when this catalyst serving as solid oxide fuel cell cathode, a considerable single cell performance with a peak power density of 880 mW cm−2 was achieved (Fig. 2j). Sometimes, during the catalytic reaction, the changes of chemical valence of metal centers usually trigger relevant phase transformation. Lin and co-workers reported that atomically dispersed Pt atom into the porous NiO nanocubes, can greatly accelerate the phase transformation to NiOOH [60]. This phenomenal was attributed to charge-transfer from Pt to Ni through O leads to a local weaker Ni–O bond. Interfacial electronic donation not only cause an electronic coupling between heterogeneous components, but also induce a crystalline phase evolution. 2.2 Interfacial coordination environment modulation of isolated single sites Interface environment of active sites has been investigated for many years in the field of interfacial catalysis. For the SACs, researches on the single atomic coordination with precision has been reported. The coordinated atoms surrounded the metal active centers can provide enough electron donation/reception through tailoring of coordination atoms, coordination numbers and second- or higher-coordination shells. On the one hand, the different coordination environment will induce different density transfer and regulate the d-band center of center atoms, optimizing the adsorption/desorption energy of intermediation. On the other hand, the different coordination atom and coordination number will trigger synergistic catalytic behavior. For example, Zhang and co-workers reported that Pt-Ru dual-metal dimers could enhance catalytic performance of hydrogen evolution reaction [61]. The synergistic adsorption behavior is favor of hydrogen bonding (Hads + Hads → H2) via L-H principle. As we know, perfect catalysts should possess uniform active sites and dispersion, while in the synthesis procedure, it is difficult to prepare such ideal catalyst bulk. Uncontrollable free motion of atoms and rigorous experimental conditions (high pressure and high temperature) make it uneven and tanglesome. Thus, how to purposeful steer the coordination of metal active centers of SACs with precision is significant and fundamental for exploring underlying nature of phenomenon and constructing primary laws of nanocatalysis. Generally, the metal active center usually coordinated with support by the formation of some non-metal elements, such as N, S, O et al. Selectively introducing foreign non-metal elements into pristine catalysts bulk, constructing desired coordination structure and optimizing d-center position of metal active sites is favor of improving the electrocatalytic performance [62,63]. The modulation of carbon materials must be given priority in electrocatalysis, because they possess many excellent physico-chemical properties, such as good ductility, conductivity and anti-corrosive ability. A pioneering work of high precision fabrication and modulation on local coordination sites was reported by Jiang and co-workers [64]. They reported that the N-C bond from the representative Fe-N4-C ORR active sites would be selectively broken via constructing amounts of pores. The undercoordinated Fe-N4 sites showed an enhanced activity by weakening the reaction energy barriers. The coordination number of SACs, an important parameter of coordination microenvironment modulation, would also greatly affect the electronic and geometric structure of metal active centers [65,66]. As shown in Fig. 3 a, Jiang’s group developed a facile post-synthetic metal substitution strategy to obtain controlled synthesis of single-atom Ni catalysts with low-coordination number on a pre-designed N-doped carbon support derived from a Zn-based MOF [67]. In general, due to low vaporize of Zn element, the obtained Zn-based ZIF-8 precursor would leave a Zn vacancy (Zn-N3 site) above 900° pyrolysis. Upon refilling Ni atom into Zn vacancies, the Ni-N3-C was formed (Fig. 3b and d). The defined Ni-N3-C catalyst shows an excellent CO Faradic efficiency, up to 95.6% with a turnover frequency of 1425 h−1 at −0.65 V in the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (Fig. 3e and f). Furthermore, the Density functional theory (DFT) results revealed that the low-coordinated Ni atoms in Ni-N3-C catalyst is in favor of formation of COOH* intermediate, leading a promoted CO2 reduction Fig. 3g. As a cathode in Zn-CO2 battery, the Ni-N3-C presents a high CO a selectivity up to 90% in the discharge process, as well as outstanding stability. Zhang and co-workers proposed that the turnover frequency of selective oxidation of C–H bond for atomically dispersed Fe active site supported on carbon with different coordination configurations (Fe-N x , x = 4–6) would be improved [68]. Thus, the coordination modulation strategy can greatly tune the specific local environment and electronic structure of metal central sites. DFT calculations demonstrated the standard symmetrical planar 4-coordination structure (denoted as M-N4 moiety) might serve as the most favorable catalytic site for ORR, seemingly supported by plenty of experimental results [69,70]. However, some researchers documented that electronegativity of the symmetrical neighboring nitrogen atoms around the metal site are not the most optimized sites structure for adsorbing intermediates and bond-breaking [71,72]. Constructing an unsymmetrically interface configuration of coordination environment of metal active center would boost the catalytic ORR activity to some extent. This regulation can tune and enhance the kinetic activity of the M-N4 species through steering electron-withdrawing/donating properties. Under the guidance of this concept, Zhang and co-workers designed and constructed an atomically dispersed Cu based coordinated with both S and N atoms in MOF-derived hierarchically porous carbon (S-Cu-ISA/SNC), as shown in Fig. 3h-k [73]. The we-defined S-Cu-ISA/SNC exhibited a half-wave potential of 0.918 V vs. RHE in basic solution, outperforming other reported catalysts (Fig. 3l and m). In addition, they found that the activity of S-Cu-ISA/SNC was higher single-atom Cu-N4 supported on N and S co-doped carbon polyhedron. The further characterizations demonstrated that the outstanding ORR activity originated from the formation of the unsymmetrical Cu-S1N3 atomic interface in the carbon matrix, and the low-valent Cu ion acted as active site for ORR (Fig. 3n and o). Li et al. presented an atomically dispersed Fe based SACs (FeCl1N4/CNS) through implanting foreign chlorine element into the lattice spacing to change the coordination configuration [74]. The obtained FeCl1N4/CNS catalyst possesses a uniform Fe site. For ORR, this catalyst showed an outstanding activity with half-wave potential of 0.921 V, and high kinetic current density of 41.11 mA cm−2. The introduction of chlorine element could tune electronic structure and coordination environment of central Fe atoms. Due to the strong chemical hybridization between single metal atoms and vicinal atoms in the supported materials, the electronic properties of single metal atoms are distinct from those of extended metallic ensembles in nanoparticles, which results in outstanding electrocatalytic performance with a higher activity and superior stability in comparison to nanoparticles. Sun’s group reported a series of different type of M-based SACs coordinated with different nonmetal elements [75–77]. Recently, they found that O-Co-C coordination figuration formed by combining graphene and atomically dispersed Co showed a superior activity of conversion of nitrobenzene to azoxy Fig. 3p [78]. They ascribed the high performance to the existence of an O-Co-C active center, which is coordinatively unsaturated and positively charged on Co. In addition, the novel Co-based SACs with various coordination environment were designed and fabricated to investigate the electrocatalytic performance, as shown in Fig. 3q-s [79]. The obtained Co-S1N2 catalyst shows excellent ORR activity with onset potential of 0.99 V vs. RHE and good durability, as well as have promising application in a zin-oxygen battery with a high power-density (260 mW cm−2) and open-circuit voltage (1.50 V) (Fig. 3t), which attributed to optimized electron structure of Co metal center by coordinating with S and N elements. Apart from the above reference, other non-N elements, such as S [80], P [81], B [82] have been introduced in the design of new coordination environment for SACs to improve the catalytic performance. Jiang and co-workers reported that the TM single atom coordination motifs can effectively tune the ORR pathways and product selectivity via experimental and theoretical results [83]. A series of transition-metal single atom catalysts, including Fe, Co, Pd and Mn, with different coordination motifs are designed and fabricated. Among them, the Fe-CNT with rich Fe-C-O shows the highest activity and selectivity towards H2O2 generation. DFT calculations suggest that the catalytically active C and Fe sites in Fe–C–O and Fe–C–N motifs are responsible for the H2O2 and H2O pathways, respectively. In addition, A Co-Nx-C site and oxygen functional group (OFGs) co-modified carbon-based electrocatalyst (named as Co–POC–O) through pyrolysis and oxidization of the cobalt-coordinated framework porphyrin precursor to electrosynthesize H2O2 with high reactivity and high selectivity is developed by Zhang’s group [84]. Modification of OFGs on nanocarbon prominently promotes the selectivity for the two-electron ORR pathway to generate H2O2. The Co–POC–O electrocatalyst shows an excellent performance for H2O2 electrochemical synthesis with selectivity over 80%. The further mechanism study revealed that the synergistic effect between Co-Nx-C sites and OFGs is in favor of high activity and selectivity of H2O2 electrochemical synthesis. 2.3 Synergistic promoting of isolated dual-atom sites In comparison with isolated single atom sites, the isolated dual-atom sites possess more advantages, not only nearly 100% atomic availability, but also strong synergistic interactions between adjacent metal active atoms. However, isolated dual-atom active sites are difficult in synthesis process, because controlling the distance of two adjacent atom needs extremely harsh conditions and complexes. Exploring the interactions between the two adjacent metal atoms in dual-atom site catalysts would be conducive to further elevating the catalytic performances and understanding the catalytic mechanisms at the atomic level. In general, isolated dual-atom sites catalysts are divided into two subcategories according to the types of two atoms: homo-dual-atom site catalysts and hetero-dual-atom sites catalysts. 2.3.1 Homo-dual-atom site catalysts Homo-dual-atom site catalysts received enormous attention by researcher recently. Due to existence of isolated atomic metal–metal interface, the electronic structure and environment of catalytic site are intricate, and the reaction mechanism is complex. Many advanced characterizations are applied to further explore corresponding structure-performance relationship. For example, Zhang et al. developed a novel preparation strategy of anion replacement deposition–precipitation (ARDP) to construct an isolated homo-dual-atom site catalyst, as shown in Fig. 4 a [85]. The Pd-Pd bonding is confirmed in Fourier transformed k3-weighted spectra; the fitting results on EXAFS indicate a Cu-Cu coordination number of 1.0, far lower than that for Pd nanoparticles (8.5), indicating that the supported Pd species exist in the form of well-isolated small clusters (Fig. 4c). Simultaneously, the HAADF-STEM characterizations present an isolated bright dual-atom pair in the dark carbon background, as shown in Fig. 4b. The above conclusions proved that the Pd2 DAC was successfully fabricated using ARDP method. The obtained Pd2 dual-atom catalysts (Pd2 DAC) showed superior CO2RR catalytic activity with 98% Faradic efficiency of CO at −0.85 V vs. RHE, as well as excellent stability (Fig. 4d and e). The underlying theoretical conclusion unveiled that the dual-atom site interface features the most favorable kinetics and thermodynamics rooting from interfacial electronic transfer between Pd atoms. Jiao’s group reported an isolated dual-atom Cu species anchored on one-dimensional Pd10Te3 alloy nanowires and used them to CO2RR [86]. The obtained catalysts containing 0.1% Cu loading exhibited a high current density of 18.74 mA cm−2 at −0.98 V vs. RHE, and gave a Faradic efficiency of 92% to CO. In this system, the “diatomic activating bimolecular” mechanism at the Cu-Cu atomic interfaces endow this catalyst with an enhanced synergistically impact on the stabilization of CO2. Doping electron withdrawing ligands to active site to bridge the two metal centers has been proved an efficient method in regulating the adsorption energy [87]. Recently, oxygen containing species with high electron negativities are proved to be optimal electron modifies to interbond OH species. However, the isolated Fe-O bond is too weak to be interrupted. For this, Gong and co-workers designed a Fe-O-Fe bridged homo-dual-atom site catalyst by approximating two Fe-N4 sites, as shown in Fig. 4f-j [88]. O element as a bridge to interbond the Fe site can not only construct a desired dual-atom site, but also modulate the electron structure and optimize the d-band center to suitable position. The obtained sample performed approximately 10 times higher activity than the single atomic Fe-N4 site. The density functional theory revealed that Fe-O-Fe bridged homo-dual-atom site catalyst could greatly reduce thermodynamic barrier towards ORR. This strategy provides an avenue to construct optimized homo-dual-atom site catalysts. 2.3.2 Hetero-dual-atom site catalysts Constructing two different heterogeneous atoms into dual-atom site catalysts will further enrich the diversity of structure and function. Lu and co-worker reported a Zn/Co-N x -C site through competitive complexation strategy [89]. They used AC-HAADF-STEM and EXAFS to clarify the existence of isolated Zn-Co hetero-dual-atom. The DFT calculations revealed that ZnCoN6 site can significantly elongate the O-O bond from the original 1.23 Å to 1.42 Å and thus facilitate the bond cleavage. The well-defined ZnCoN6 site catalyst show superior ORR performance, deriving from the heteroatom interface electron transfer. In addition, the corresponding Zn-air battery presented a maximum power density of 230 mW cm−2. Xie’s group demonstrated a NiSn atomic-pair electrocatalyst (NiSn-APC) on a hierarchical integrated electrode, which exhibits a synergistic effect in simultaneously promoting the activity and selectivity of the CO2RR to formate [90]. The combination of HAADF-STEM and EXAFS characterizations proved that the Ni and Sn atoms are bigeminy (Fig. 5 a-c). The as-prepared NiSn-APC shows an excellent activity for CO2RR with a turnover frequency of 4752 h−1. In specific, the formate yield is about 36.7 mol hSn −1 and the utilization degree of active sites could be up to 57.9% (Fig. 5d and e). The additional calculations and characterizations revealed that electron structure of Sn greatly imposed by adjacent Ni, optimizing the energy barrier of the *OCHO intermediate, as shown in Fig. 5f. The synergistic effect of Co and Fe hetero-dual-atom site catalysts were also demonstrated by Li and co-workers [91]. They used FeCl3 as precursor and encapsulated it into the cavities of ZnCo-ZIF-8. Treated under high temperature, the Fe3+ was reduced and anchored on the vacancies, where was generated by volatilized Zn atoms. The obtained dual-atom (Fe,Co)/N-C catalyst was fabricated, which was identified by HAADF-STEM and EXAFS characterizations. In ORR test, the (Fe,Co)/N-C catalyst shows a great catalytic performance in comparison with Co/N-C catalyst and Fe/N-C catalyst. DFT results demonstrated that the cleavage barrier of O O bond would be reduced on the Fe Co dual sites through weakening the O=O bond energy. Liu’s group reported an atomically dispersed Fe-Zn pairs supported on porous N-doped carbon materials (Fe-Zn-SA/NC), as shown in Fig. 5g [92]. The presence of dual-atom Fe-Zn site was identified by electron energy-loss spectroscopy and EXAFS characterizations (Fig. 5h and i). They found that the Fe-Zn as atomic pair via directly interbonding surrounded by six pyridinic-atoms. The obtained Fe-Zn-SA/NC shows excellent ORR activities in all-over pH range. The half-wave potentials are 0.78, 0.85, and 0.72 V in acidic, basic, and neutral solutions, respectively (Fig. 5j and k). The DFT results demonstrated that the reaction energy barrier on the Fe-Zn-SA/NC is lower than single atom site catalysts (Fig. 5j and k). 2.4 Synergistic promoting of atomic interface between single atom and nanoparticles At present, great breakthroughs have been made in the preparation of SACs, but how to find a reasonable, simple and feasible strategy to improve the electrocatalytic performance of SACs is still the bottleneck of its large-scale application. According to the current experimental and theoretical results, the microenvironment of monatomic catalyst is complex and changeable, and the electronic structure and coordination environment of metal active center are also dynamically evolving during the catalytic process, which leads to the variability of catalyst structure and the complexity of catalytic reaction mechanism [93–99]. In addition, during the reaction process, the unstable single atom site migrate and aggregate to each other, forming a large-sized nanoparticle. In some cases, the catalytic performance of SACs would present a tremendous improvement, which may be attribute the synergistic effect between single atom site and nanoparticle. Have been puzzled by this phenomenon for years, researchers made many efforts to explore the intrinsic reason to reveal the catalytic behavior under such complicated system. Among them, the most facile and directly method is to construct atom-nanoparticle interface to prove the synergistic interaction on electrocatalytic activity. For example, Chong and co-workers developed a facile method to construct a novel nanocatalyst containing single atomic Co sites and strained Pt3Co/Pt core/shell nanoparticles, as shown in Fig. 6 a-c [100]. Synergistic catalysis between strained Pt-Co core–shell nanoparticles over a platinum-group metal–free catalytic substrate led to excellent fuel cell performance under 1 atmosphere of O2 or air at both high-voltage and high-current domains (Fig. 6d and e). It is noted that, excepting single atomic Co sites and strained Pt3Co/Pt core/shell nanoparticles, there is another existence of Co active site is encapsulated in onion-like graphitic layers, which is also considered an efficiency catalytic center for ORR. The further DFT calculations revealed that interaction between Pt-Co nanoparticles and atomic Co sites improves ORR activity and durability (Fig. 6f). On the one hand, Pt-Co nanoparticle provides enough active sites for performing directly ORR. On the other hand, the atomic Co active sites can facilitate the reduction of H2O2, causing a four-electron transfer. Guided by this achievement, more works were reported to design and optimize this synergistic catalyst. As we known, the alloy structure, crystal phase, size, composition, are the efficient factors for improving catalytic performance, as well as the key parameters for systemically and rationally designing catalysts. Liu’s group constructed an ordered intermetallic PtFe nanoparticles and supported them on the atomically dispersed Fe based N-doped carbon materials [101]. As shown in Fig. 6g, it is clearly seen that the single atom and alloy were co-existed on the N-doped carbon materials, which is further demonstrated by the XAS characterizations (Fig. 6h and i). In the ORR measurement, the obtained PtA@FeSA–N–C catalyst possesses an excellent performance with a half-wave potential of 0.923 V. vs. RHE, and non-negligible activity loss after 5000 cycles stability (Fig. 6j and k). After the deep-exploration, the authors revealed that the structure of PtFe alloy is ordered intermetallic Pt3M as the core and enriched Pt atoms on the shell surface, which is in favor of enhanced ORR performance. The existence of Fe in the Fe-NC substrate could also enhance ORR activity via providing amounts of active sites. Theoretical calculations suggest that the ORR activity of the Fe–N4 sites may be enhanced by adjacent Pt (100). Considering the above summaries, the atom-alloy interface is beneficial for electrocatalytic performance. In the water dissociation, non-Pt noble metals, such as Ru, Rh, Pd, obtained enormous attentions recently [101–105]. Baek et al. reported that Rh nanoparticles supported on the porous N-doped carbon showed an excellent catalytic performance of water dissociation [102]. However, some studies indicated the remarkable performance of Ru is derived from the atomically dispersed Ru active sites instead of Ru particles. Chen’s group demonstrated that atomic Ru active center coordinated with N and C is in favor of water dissociation than Rh nanoparticle, because the Ru single atom possesses a lower dissociation kinetic barrier [104]. Wang and co-workers designed and fabricated a particle-single-atom, partial nanoparticle nanocomposite through coupling of Ru single atom and Ru nanoparticles supported on the N-doped carbon materials [106]. The author found that the dispersed atomically Fe active center in the carbon matrix could disperse the large-sized Ru nanoparticles into Ru single atoms (Fig. 7 a-c). The obtained Ru based catalyst shows an excellent HER performance with a lower overpotential (9 mV) at 10 mA cm−2, a high turnover frequency and nearly 100% Faradic efficiency (Fig. 7 d and e). In addition, the Fe-N structure can efficient tune the electronic structure of Ru nanoparticles, resulting in an optimized Gibbs free energy. As shown in Fig. 7f, the deep DFT calculations disclose that Ru–N4 moieties facilitate the splitting of water molecules and the generation of hydrogen adsorbates that then recombine into hydrogen molecules on the nearby smaller Ru NPs. Under the synergistic promotion of atomic Ru atom-particle interface, the energy barrier of water dissociation was reduced by Ru single atoms, while the Ru nanoparticles could adjust the hydrogen adsorption/desorption strength. Synergistic effect of atom-particle interface gives a unique view to understanding reaction mechanism based on the superior electrocatalytic performance. Hou’s group reported an outstanding Ni based SACs with abundant atom-particle interfaces based on proton capture strategy [107]. They constructed the Ni nanoparticles adjacent to atomically dispersed Ni-NC sites to accelerate the proton transfer to the latter for enhancing the intermediate protonation step. Firstly, they modelled Ni nanoparticles supported on the N-doped carbon matrix with atomically dispersed Ni active atoms, as shown in Fig. 7g. They found that as-modelled Ni@NiN4CM showed a strong valence band peak comprised of strengthened d-states from the Ni atoms. In addition, the states around the Fermi level reveal that the Ni@NiN4CM structure possesses a more obvious electron transfer ability than that of NiN4CM SACs (Fig. 7h). Guided by this theory, the as-prepared Ni@NiNCM shows excellent CO2RR performance (Fig. 7i-k). Thus, engineering rational atom-level interface is an efficient method to enhance the electrocatalytic performance. 3 Conclusions and perspective SACs have attracted great attention in electrocatalysis due to the maximized atomic utilization and unique electron/coordination structure. In this review, we summarized recent process about design, preparation, application of atomic sites catalysts based on the atom-level interfacial catalysis. Firstly, we demonstrated the intrinsic property of SACs relating the electronic structure and coordination environment, which govern the catalytic behavior of SACs. On this basis, we further elaborate how does they affect the catalytic performance and propose regulation strategy on the electronic structure and coordination environment to improve the catalytic performance. Targeted modifying the d-band center position via electron coupling and precious constructing the coordination environment of isolated active sites of SACs is difficult and necessary for researchers to recognize its essence from a theoretical point of view. Secondly, the dual-atom sites catalysts were presented to clarify the atomic interface synergy by adjacent metal atoms coupling, such as, metal–metal interboning, or metal-X-metal interbonding (X, non-metal element). How to engineer isolated atomic pairs by an efficient strategy, simultaneously avoid the co-existence of massive atoms is a challenge. Finally, atom-particle interface exhibited excellent synergistic catalysis towards electrocatalytic reaction. Engineering abundant atom-particle interfaces could efficient steer reaction pathway via collaboration. Generally, the nanoparticle possesses strong adsorption activation ability toward reactant and the single-atom sites can propel reactions via trapping electron. Despite great progresses have already been achieved, many essential issues of SACs remain and should be addressed in future. Herein, we listed several challenges of SACs to demonstrate the necessary and design principle of advanced SACs via interfacial regulation strategy. (i) Precious characterization of catalysis sites: despite enormous analysis techniques have been widely applied to determine the true atom structure of SACs, the manifest results to us still are the average information regarding atom structure and coordination number, as well as reaction pathway and mechanisms. In addition, the DFT calculations are also used to model the corresponding catalyst structure and reaction pathway, which was built on the foregone structure. Without the defined local structure, DFT calculations become not very meaningful. In order to solve this dilemma, new design concept and synthesis method should be explored and developed to further precisely control the catalysts structure from the atom level. Thus, atom-level interfacial regulation can provide an efficient avenue for deep understanding of isolated active sites. (ii) Intricate dynamic structural evolution process: As we know, according to the current experimental and theoretical results, the microenvironment of SACs is complex and changeable, and the electronic structure and coordination environment of metal active center are also dynamically evolving during the catalytic process, which leads to the variability of catalyst structure and the complexity of catalytic reaction mechanism. The precise site control of monatomic catalyst can effectively control the catalytic reaction process and reaction path. This review endows the readers a fundamental understanding for design and prepare SACs from interfacial site regulation. (iii) Fixed-point regulation strategy of SACs: the precise modification for isolated atoms of SACSs is a bottleneck problem for large-scale preparation. It is necessary to introduce a fixed-point coupled ligand to anchor certain active center and steer their physico-chemical property for constructing desired atomic interface. In addition, designing an ideal defective support to engineer cooperative interface is an efficient via confined strategy. Yao Wang is currently a postdoctoral researcher fellow under the supervision of Prof. Yadong Li and Prof. Dingsheng Wang at the Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University. He received his Ph.D. degree at College of Chemical Engineering and Environment, China University of Petroleum (Beijing) in 2020 under the supervision of Prof. Xin Zhang. He is interested in synthesis of nanomaterials, clusters, and isolated single-atom sites, as well as focuses on their catalytic applications based on specific functions. Dingsheng Wang received his B.S. degree from the Department of Chemistry and Physics, University of Science and Technology of China in 2004, and his Ph.D. degree from the Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University in 2009 under the supervision of Prof. Yadong Li. He did his postdoctoral research at the Department of Physics, Tsinghua University, with Prof. Shoushan Fan. He joined the faculty of the Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University in 2012. His research interests focus on the synthesis, assembly, and catalytic applications of nanomaterials, clusters, and isolated single-atom sites. Yadong Li received his B.S. degree from the Department of Chemistry at Anhui Normal University in 1986 and his Ph.D. from the Department of Chemistry at the University of Science and Technology of China in 1998. He joined the faculty of the Department of Chemistry at Tsinghua University in 1999. He was elected as member of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2011. His research interests focus on the synthesis, assembly, and catalytic applications of nanomaterials, clusters, and isolated single-atom sites.

coredata.dc:description: Single-atom site catalysts (SACs) have made great achievements due to their nearly 100% atomic utilization and uniform active sites. Regulating the surrounding environment of active sites, including electron structure and coordination environment via atom-level interface regulation, to design and construct an advanced SACs is of great significance for boosting electrocatalytic reactions. In this review, we systemically summarized the fundamental understandings and intrinsic mechanisms of SACs for electrocatalytic applications based on the interface site regulations. We elaborated the several different regulation strategies of SACs to demonstrate their ascendancy in electrocatalytic applications. Firstly, the interfacial electronic interaction was presented to reveal the electron transfer behavior of active sites. Secondly, the different coordination structures of metal active center coordinated with two or three non-metal elements were also summarized. In addition, other atom-level interfaces of SACs, including metal atom–atom interface, metal atom-X-atom interface (X: non-metal element), metal atom-particle interface, were highlighted and the corresponding promoting effect towards electrocatalysis was disclosed. Finally, we outlooked the limitations, perspectives and challenges of SACs based on atomic interface regulation.
